“The Truth of Masks”

By Amy on 08 December 2015 in Chicago

Tweet

Richard Gray Gallery features a comprehensive exhibition of John Stezaker’s collages.

A carefully placed postcard mostly covers the faces of a posed couple. Three people make up another scene; their bodies and faces are merely outlines, filled in with layers of images. A woman’s face in a black and white portrait is entirely covered by a postcard. Each collage is distinct, but they are united by their “masked” appearance.

The artist behind these images is John Stezaker, a British conceptual artist that has used postcards, photographs and film stills in his work for decades. Stezaker’s current exhibition at Richard Gray Gallery in Chicago reveals the artist’s strength in juxtaposing images. The subsequent new forms may look quickly put together, however, they are carefully arranged.

Take “Pair XXV,” where a black and white portrait depicts a man and woman impeccably dressed and posed. The couple leans in the same direction, and perfection radiates: not even a strand of hair is out of place. Facing the viewer, their faces are partially covered with a nature-themed postcard.

The Transformation of the Milwaukee Art Museum

By Amy on 22 November 2015 in Chicago

Tweet

A $34 million project reinvigorates one of the nation’s oldest art museums.

The renovations and addition at the Milwaukee Art Museum (MAM), one of the nation’s oldest, are both dynamic and refreshing; excitement has been growing as the November 24 reopening nears. The six year, $34 million project includes the re-envisioning of its Collection Galleries and structural updates to the MAM’s Eero Saarinen-designed War Memorial Center and David Kahler-designed extension, along with a new east entry addition. These changes enhance visitor flow and allow 2,500 artworks to be displayed within these spaces from the Museum’s 30,000 piece collection.

Experience is a repeated theme throughout the MAM’s history and its current project. The Museum’s 1957 War Memorial Center was built to commemorate those who served in the World Wars. Instead of a statue, “it was built as an experience,” Daniel Keegan, Director at MAM, explains. The 1975 Kahler addition originally included an east end “glass curtain wall,” as Chief Curator Brady Roberts describes it, which was “blocked off” over time in order to create additional galleries and to safeguard the art. That said, beyond structural repairs, the project aimed to reconnect the Museum with views of Lake Michigan, and to create a more flowing floor plan. In short, “we wanted to fundamentally change the experience with the art,” Keegan says.

Art and the Sharing Economy

By Amy on 17 November 2015 in Chicago

Tweet

How today’s sharing economy is influencing the production and consumption of art.

“We couldn’t have existed ten years ago, before Facebook, because people weren’t really into sharing,” one of Airbnb’s founders, Nate Blecharczyk, has said. He has a point. People are willing to share just about everything today: renting a room in someone’s home through Airbnb or a bike with Divvy, Chicago’s “bike sharing system;” others are content sharing pictures of lavish vacations or unique experiences on social media. This sharing mentality coincides with today’s sharing economy, which is upending production and consumption behaviors in the arts.

Helen Molesworth, an art historian and curator, made a compelling observation between art and the post-war American economy in her essay, “Work Ethic.” She argues that post-World War II avant garde art corresponded with the changing post-war American economy, from a manufacturing economy to a post-industrial one grounded in services and managerial labor. That is, from producing goods to overseeing the labor of others, she explains, and offers this example: Conceptual artists relied on language and directions for others to complete, thereby functioning like a manager; other artists gave themselves tasks, and performed them. Renouncing traditional artistic materials to produce an art object, “artists came to see themselves . . . as workers in capitalist America.”

Continue reading

Merging Technology and Art

By Amy on 11 November 2015 in Chicago

Tweet

The “Feel Flows” exhibition at Fernwey gallery reveals how today’s digital and physical worlds are merging.

It is no surprise that technology is infiltrating life today. The internet and social media have had a revolutionary impact, but these technologies are just the beginning of what is to come. The debut of self-driving cars, the Internet of Things and improvements to virtual reality have the potential to upend life as we know it. Indeed our digital and physical worlds are colliding.

The “Feel Flows” exhibition at Fernwey gallery in Chicago captures this merge. The show consists of Katie Pennachio’s paintings and Matt Mancini’s sculptures, along with an edition series each artist made in collaboration with the gallery in a different medium. Despite the physical presence of their artwork, a digital aesthetic emanates. Both artists incorporate digital technologies in their practices, and their influence is demonstrated here.
